content.title: BUSINESS MODELS AND FINANCING MECHANISMS FOR ENERGY ACCESS
content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 3 | Lesson 3

content.text: Lesson 3 Overview

To expand sustainable and inclusive energy access it si essential to have the right business models and financing strategies that can reach the underserved, attract investment, and ensure long-term affordability. This lesson explores how tailored financial instruments and delivery models are transforming the energy access landscape, especially in remote, rural, and low-income communities. There are a wide range of financing mechanisms related to increasing access to energy - such as funds, bonds, debt swaps, carbon finance initiatives, among others. Describing all such mechanisms is not the purpose of this lesson - they are covered in Module 4 - Sustainable Energy Finance and Investment. From results-based financing that rewards energy providers for delivering measurable outcomes, to Energy-as-a-Service (EaaS) models that remove the barrier of upfront costs, innovative approaches are helping scale decentralized renewable energy solutions. At the same time, end-user-focused tools like pay-as-you-go (PAYG) systems and green microfinance are enabling households and small businesses to access and afford clean energy services on flexible terms. Finally, this lesson also highlights the importance of community-led initiatives and participatory design processes. These approaches not only ensure energy solutions are tailored to local needs, but also promote ownership, resilience, and long-term impact

content.title: Key Concepts
content.intro: Explore foundational ideas from this lesson.

concepts.title: microfinancing
concepts.body: Microfinancing is a financial service that provides small loans and financial support to individuals or small businesses, typically in developing countries, to help them start or expand their operations.

concepts.title: pay as you go models
concepts.body: Pay as you go models are payment systems where customers pay for services or products in advance or as they use them, rather than committing to long-term contracts or upfront costs.

concepts.title: result-based financing models
concepts.body: Result-based financing models are financial mechanisms that provide funding based on the achievement of specific outcomes or results, rather than on the inputs or processes used to achieve them.

content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 3 | Lesson 3 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1: Energy Services Providers

content.text: Part 1 Overview

Energy service providers play a central role in expanding sustainable energy access, especially in underserved regions where high upfront costs and operating expenses pose substantial barriers. This section explores innovative mechanisms and case studies, illustrating how they are transforming energy service delivery and making sustainable access viable for communities facing significant capital challenges.

For energy services providers, tailored financial mechanisms play a pivotal role in unlocking the capital necessary for the development of sustainable and inclusive energy projects. These mechanisms enable the implementation of clean energy initiatives and ensure that energy providers can operate efficiently and expand their reach, ultimately bringing energy access to a broader populace. Financial mechanisms for energy service providers typically require considerable investments and recurring costs for the state budget. Many developing countries struggle to combine fiscal and environmental sustainability, while also expanding access to energy. Therefore, innovative partnerships forged among governments, financial institutions, the private sector and development agencies can play a pivotal role in supporting the expansion of energy access and scaling up clean energy projects, particularly in regions with limited access to capital. Such partnerships can make upfront costs more manageable, reduce long-term operational costs, and also be designed to contribute to environmental sustainability.
Example: Rwanda Renewable Energy Project Fund

This project was implemented by the Government of Rwanda in partnership with the Development Bank of Rwanda, management support from the World Bank Group, and financing from the Climate Investment Fundsâ€™ (CIF) Scaling Up Renewable Energy Program. The project set up a fund for financing private sector engagement in off-grid electrification. The fund aims to promote private sector-led, off-grid renewable energy development by providing lines of credit and creating an enabling environment for off-grid electrification. The core intervention at the heart of the project lies in the creation of lines of credit in local currency for financial institutions to finance solar home systems and minigrids, and solar companies offering those solutions (Source: CIF, 2022).
Results-based financing models

Results-Based Financing (RBF) models are increasingly gaining traction as a mechanism to incentivize energy service providers to reach underserved populations. These models tie financial incentives to the achievement of defined energy access goals. In essence, they reward successful expansion of energy services to those who need it most. RBF has proven to be an effective strategy in catalyzing the expansion of energy access and accelerating the transition to cleaner and more sustainable energy sources. According to SEforALL, RBF is "proven to deliver connections faster and more efficiently. Governments and donors offer grants to project developers that are paid upon delivery of energy connections. Thus the risks of delivery are shifted to the private sector while companies are incentivized to build at speed and scale" (source: SEforAll Results-Based Financing). RBF is a strategic approach that shifts the focus from merely funding projects and initiatives to achieving defined outcomes. It operates on the principle of paying for results achieved and performance against pre-established targets. This results-oriented approach is particularly valuable in energy projects because it provides a direct link between funding and the impact on beneficiaries.

One of the core principles of RBF is incentivizing energy service providers to reach underserved populations and attain energy access goals. These incentives can be financial rewards, grants, or subsidies, often tied to specific performance indicators. For instance, energy providers may receive payments upon successfully connecting a certain number of households to the grid or installing a specific capacity of renewable energy infrastructure. Nevertheless, it is often suggested to select targets closer to outcomes than to outputs, to reduce the risk of disincentivizing and/or neglecting key dimensions of a program. RBF models have the potential to significantly scale up energy access projects, particularly in underserved regions. By linking payments to results, governments and development organizations motivate energy providers to expand their operations in areas that are traditionally considered financially unattractive, such as remote rural communities. Project implementers are required to demonstrate the achievement of specific milestones or targets. This not only ensures that funds are used effectively but also enhances the trust and credibility of energy access projects, which can be especially crucial in attracting additional investments. While Results-Based Financing models offer numerous advantages, they are not without challenges. Setting realistic and measurable targets can be complex, and verification processes must be rigorous. Moreover, RBF models require strong governance and financial systems to manage the disbursement of incentives effectively.
Energy-as-a-Service (EaaS)

Energy-as-a-Service (EaaS) is an business model that shifts the traditional energy supply model from selling electricity by the kilowatt-hour to providing tailored energy services. Instead of purchasing energy infrastructure directly, customers pay for services such as lighting, cooling, or productive energy use through subscription or performance-based contracts (IRENA., 2020). . This approach can be particularly impactful in developing countries, where upfront costs and financing barriers prevent many households and institutions from accessing clean, reliable electricity. For instance, EaaS enables off-grid customers to access distributed renewable energy solutions like solar PV and battery storage without the need to purchase them upfront, thereby accelerating access to modern energy services. In the EaaS model, Energy Service Providers (ESPs) offer bundled services, including the design, installation, financing, and operation of energy systems. For example, ESPs can install solar home systems or mini-grids in rural communities and manage the systems remotely using smart technologies. These models can educe high entry costs for consumers and provide a reliable, affordable alternative to diesel generators or grid expansion. In India for instance, the National Smart Grid Mission is deploying 250 million smart meters to enable dynamic pricing and service contracts that improve energy reliability for underserved populations (Government of India, 2020) EaaS can also support the deployment of decentralized renewable energy systems which are crucial for rural electrification in developing regions. In South Africa, for example, pilot-scale smart grid projects backed by the South African National Energy Development Initiative used EaaS models to enhance access and reduce peak demand (Smart Energy International., 2017). These models also help public institutions: hospitals and schools can subscribe to solar-as-a-service contracts that ensure reliable electricity without needing to operate or maintain the equipment themselves.

EaaS providers can also use smart meters, load management tools, and AI-based controls to help consumers manage their electricity use more efficiently, for instance by reducing consumption when electricity prices are highest. This approach, known as demand-side management, can lower peak electricity demand by 3â€“10% and reduce overall energy costs for low-income households and small businesses. In developing countries, many EaaS providers also rely on mobile platforms to share real-time energy use and pricing information with customers, with the potential to make energy services more accessible and user-friendly. EaaS may also create opportunities for local entrepreneurship. Rural energy cooperatives and small enterprises can act as service providers under franchised or licensed EaaS models. The company Husk Power Systems is an example of the Energy-as-a-Service model as it designs, owns, and operates renewable energy mini-grids that deliver reliable electricity to rural communities in India and Nigeria. As of January 2025, Husk operates over 400 mini-grids, providing power to more than 1.5 million people and over 30,000 small businesses ( Solar Quarter., 2025). These mini-grids integrate solar photovoltaic and biomass gasification technologies, ensuring a continuous 24/7 power supply. Customers access electricity through flexible, pay-as-you-go plans facilitated by mobile-enabled smart meters. This approach also fosters economic growth by enabling businesses to operate more efficiently and creating local employment opportunities.

content.title: Part 2: End Users

content.text: Part 2 Overview

At the user level, innovative financial approaches work to make energy services more accessible and affordable. Examples include Pay-As-You-Go financing models and Microfinance/Green Microfinance schemes, outlined below.
Pay-as-you-go (PAYG) models

These financing models have witnessed a surge in popularity in recent years, supported by the proliferation of mobile phone use and digital banking applications. PAYG models allow users to avoid paying high upfront installation costs by make incremental payments for energy services. This renders the services more accessible and budget-friendly. The widespread use of mobile phones can contribute to enhancing the efficiency of PAYG systems by enabling seamless mobile money transactions, remote payment tracking, and real-time activation or deactivation of services, thus reducing operational costs for service providers.
Example: Sun King PAYG

Sun King (previously Greenlight Planet), operates in Kenya, Nigeria, Tanzania and Uganda, enabling most customers to make roughly 60 mobile money payments between 2 to 5 USD each over a period of 12 to 24 months to complete their instalment payment plans for a solar home system.
Microfinancing Models

These models, which can include Green Microfinancing and Social Entrepreneurship Financing aim to help financially excluded people, primarily in the Global South, to manage and reduce the insecurity of their income, including by empowering them to set up profitable micro-enterprises. Green Microfinance (GMF) includes an additional focus, focusing on loans that address environmental concerns while maintaining positive financial and social performance (ISC 2020).

Microfinancing schemes can serve as powerful levers for transformative change at both local and systemic levels, as long as they are thoughtfully designed and take into account the needs and aspirations of marginalized groups such as women, Indigenous Peoples, and youth (ISC, 2020). Among these models, green microfinance stands out for its dual role in advancing inclusive development and environmental sustainability. Green microfinance refers to financial servicesâ€”such as microloans, revolving funds, or credit schemesâ€”specifically tailored to enable low-income households and small enterprises to invest in clean energy, climate adaptation technologies, and sustainable livelihood practices. These schemes often include tiered pricing structures and flexible repayment models, allowing recipients to repay loans in small increments based on their income flows. An example fo such initiative is the EcoMicro programme in Latin America which is building the capacity of 12 microfinance institutions to design financial products for clean energy and energy efficiency (UNFCCC., 2023). In Mexico and Peru, EcoMicro is expected to mobilize USD 5.9 million in green finance for over 5,000 small businesses, enabling them to reduce emissions by up to 20%. Similarly, the UNDP-supported Small Grants Programme (SGP) has enabled micro-credit schemes in Costa Rica and Vietnam to support sustainable agriculture and solar-powered fish sauce production (UNDP., 2022) . Through this program, in Ghana, a village savings and credit scheme tied to eco-charcoal production has generated income for 1,800 farmers while reducing noxious emissions by 70%.
Benefits of microfinancing

Microfinancing has the potential to unlock economic opportunities and expand access to essential services for millions of people who remain excluded from traditional financial systems. When designed thoughtfully, it can address barriers to energy access, support climate resilience, and empower communities to invest in solutions that improve their well-being. If not well-designed, however, microfinancing schemes may present problems for end users. To avoid potential pitfalls, it is very important to: Ensure products and schemes actively include women by offering products tailored to their needs and engaging local womenâ€™s groups in program design and implementation. Establish fair loan terms with flexible, income-based repayment options to avoid overburdening families and excluding the poorest households. Guide users toward reliable technology by providing clear information and quality standards, reducing the risk of low-cost, unreliable choices. It's important to remember that energy needs extend beyond the household level. Farming communities, entrepreneurs, and various other groups may possess specific and unique requirements that necessitate tailored financial programs. Many such communities take the lead in devising their own energy access solutions, requiring a different form of support and financial solutions to empower their self-sufficiency and resilience. The acknowledgment of this diversity in energy access needs and community-driven initiatives is paramount in achieving an equitable and all-encompassing approach to energy access.

content.title: Part 3: Community-Led Projects

content.text: Part 3 Overview

Community-Led Projects are initiatives where local communities take the lead in designing, implementing, and managing energy solutions. This section presents the different type of partners and the key components for a proper consultation process.

Different partners bring unique benefits to community-led projects. Local communities and grassroots organizations are vital stakeholders in expanding energy access, as their involvement ensures that projects meet specific needs and enhance well-being. Local governments play a key role by providing infrastructure and regulations, serving as intermediaries to secure funding and technical assistance. External organizations, such as NGOs and international development agencies, offer technical expertise, funding, and capacity-building support. Local communities and grassroots organizations are integral stakeholders in efforts to expand energy access, as they are the primary beneficiaries and directly affected by these projects. Recognizing their importance and involving them in decision-making processes is essential for the success and sustainability of initiatives aimed at providing energy services to underserved areas. Local communities are the end-users of energy access solutions. Their daily lives, economic activities, and overall well-being are directly impacted by the availability and reliability of energy services. Thus, they are not just passive beneficiaries but active participants who should be involved in shaping and implementing energy projects.

Community-led projects are initiatives where local communities take the lead in designing, implementing, and managing energy solutions. These projects are usually based on a deep understanding of local conditions and the active involvement of community members. They promote self-sufficiency and ownership of energy services. Local governments play a crucial role in supporting community-led projects by providing necessary infrastructure, regulations, and facilitating access to resources. They can serve as intermediaries between communities and external organizations, helping to secure funding and technical assistance without overshadowing the community's role. External organizations, such as non-governmental organizations and international development agencies, can play a supporting role by providing technical expertise, funding, and capacity building. However, they should always work in partnership with local communities, respecting their autonomy and priorities.

Inclusive and informed consultation with local communities is fundamental. It involves actively engaging with community members to understand their needs, preferences, and concerns regarding energy access. Effective consultation creates a sense of ownership and empowers communities to take an active role in decision-making.
Components of Proper Consultation:

Inclusivity: Consultation should involve all community members, ensuring the voices of marginalized groups, such as women and vulnerable populations, are heard and acted upon. Transparency: Information about the project, its objectives, and potential benefits should be communicated clearly. Active and Informed Participation: Communities should have access to information in a format that is easily accessible to them prior to the engagement; they also require opportunities to express their views, ask questions, and provide input. Feedback Mechanisms: Establish feedback mechanisms that allow communities to continuously engage and share their thoughts throughout the project's lifecycle. Community-led projects are vital for ensuring sustainability, as they are based on a deep understanding of local conditions and the active involvement of community members. They promote self-sufficiency and ownership of energy services.

content.title: Part 4: Participatory Diagnosis, Design, Monitoring, and Evaluation (PDME) in Energy Access

content.text: Part 4 Overview

PDME are integral components of a community-driven approach to building energy access solutions. With the support of local governments and external organizations, these processes empower local communities to actively participate in shaping, implementing, and assessing energy projects, ensuring that the solutions are tailored to their needs and preferences. PDME can enhance project effectiveness, promote sustainability, and empower communities to take ownership of their energy future.
Participatory Diagnosis of the Community's Energy Needs

Collaboratively identifying and understanding the energy needs, existing practices, and challenges within a specific community. This phase involves engagement with community members through workshops, surveys, interviews, and discussions. Key activities include: Conducting a needs assessment: Understanding the specific energy needs and priorities of the different groups that make up the community (e.g., lighting, cooking, or heating). Evaluating existing energy practices: Determining how the community currently meets its energy needs. Identifying barriers and challenges: Identifying obstacles that hinder access to reliable and clean energy (e.g., affordability, infrastructure limitations, or environmental concerns).
Participatory Design of the Community's Energy Solutions

Working closely with the community to develop energy solutions that align with their needs, preferences, and aspirations. This phase includes co-designing systems, technologies, and services. to ensure they are culturally and contextually appropriate, thereby increasing the likelihood of acceptance and long-term use. Key activities include: Technology Selection: Based on energy needs, available resources, and environmental considerations. Infrastructure Planning: Involving community members in planning the layout and distribution of energy infrastructure. Capacity Building: Enabling community members to actively participate in the design and maintenance of energy systems.
Participatory Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) of Energy Projects

Ongoing community engagement to assess the progress and impact of energy projects. Participatory M&E provides two major benefits: First, it ensures that energy solutions remain responsive to the changing needs of the community. Second, it empowers community members to hold project implementers accountable and advocate for improvements. Key activities: Continuously gathering data on the project's performance in a sex-disaggregated manner (e.g., energy access levels, usage patterns, and user satisfaction). Engaging community members to provide feedback, report issues, and suggest improvements. Evaluating the impacts (social, economic, and environmental) of energy access on the community. By involving community members throughout the project lifecycle, energy initiatives are more likely to succeed in improving the quality of life, fostering economic development, and enhancing overall well-being.

content.title: Case Study : Vanuatu

content.text: Case Study SIDS: Wintua-Lorlow Electrical Cooperative

Despite the significant increase in energy access across Small Island Developing States (SIDS), some islands still experience low electrification rates and high reliance on non-renewable sources (See image at the bottom of this section). These challenges are exacerbated by climate change and natural hazards, placing resilience at the forefront of regional energy policies. However, further innovative approaches are required to accelerate electrification and the integration of renewable energy solutions in SIDS. In response, Vanuatu is seizing renewable energy to expand access, currently available to only 33% of its population. In September 2020, the communities of Wintua and Lorlow inaugurated a community-owned solar micro-grid.This local management structure helps keep electricity costs low by avoiding external operation costs. In addition, these communities have set up an energy cooperative in partnership with the Department of Cooperatives to manage the collection of electricity fees.

Access to reliable and sustainable energy is a game-changer for remote communities. The introduction of the solar micro-grid is estimated to improve the lives of the 2,814 people living in Wintua and Lorlow. By providing electricity to essential community services such as schools, health care, police stations, community halls, market areas and the airport, it facilitates better educational and health outcomes and enhances local livelihoods. The shift towards electrical cooking methods has also advanced gender equality, allowing women to allocate less time to traditional tasks like firewood collection and more to educational and entrepreneurial pursuits.

The initiative is closely aligned with Vanuatuâ€™s Community Resilience Framework, which highlights that measures should be grounded in communityâ€™s own strengths and values. The success of local ownership and expertise in the Wintua-Lorlow Electrical Cooperative demonstrates the effectiveness of such approaches. Expanding similar projects throughout Vanuatu and other SIDS is essential to address the regional energy challenges comprehensively.

Expanding energy access to underserved and marginalized communities is a complex and multifaceted challenge that often requires the collaboration of various stakeholders. While governments and international organizations play significant roles in promoting energy access, partnerships and the engagement of stakeholders from diverse sectors are vital to driving successful outcomes.

content.title: Key Takeaways
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

takeaways.title: Financial mechanisms aimed at energy service providers can unlock the capital needed for expanding the availability of energy services - while also promoting inclusivity, affordability, and clean energy technologies.

Mechanisms for end users often focus on affordability - helping uses avoid high up-costs for obtaining energy access, and helping to manage ongoing maintenance costs. These include pay-as-you-go (PAYG) and Microfinancing, among others.

Farming communities, entrepreneurs, and various other groups have specific and unique requirements that necessitate tailored financial programs. Acknowledgment of this diversity is key to achieving an equitable and all-encompassing approach to energy access.
